content: The Act titled "At-Risk Youth Medicaid Protection Act of 2014" aims to protect at-risk youth under Medicaid. The "At-Risk Youth Medicaid Protection Act of 2014" amends Section 1902 of the Social Security Act to ensure that states cannot terminate enrollment for medical assistance for eligible juvenile inmates of public institutions, but may suspend it instead. The "At-Risk Youth Medicaid Protection Act of 2014" amends Section 1902 of the Social Security Act to ensure that states cannot terminate enrollment for medical assistance for eligible juvenile inmates of public institutions, but may suspend it instead. The Act requires states to enroll individuals in medical assistance upon release from a public institution and process applications for juvenile inmates. The term 'juvenile' refers to individuals under 19 years of age or as defined in subsection (a)(10)(A)(i)(IX). An 'eligible juvenile' is a juvenile inmate of a public institution enrolled in medical assistance before or during their incarceration. 'Inmate of a public institution' is defined accordingly. The amendments made by subsection (a) shall apply to eligibility and enrollment of juveniles who become inmates of public institutions. States with medical assistance plans under title XIX of the Social Security Act may need legislation to meet the new requirements. Failure to meet these requirements before the specified deadline will not automatically deem the state plan non-compliant. The Act specifies that the provisions apply after the first regular session of the State legislature following the enactment. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session.
